topic: GST for IT Professionals and Freelancers - 2024 Update

key_points.question: Do IT professionals earning 10 LPA need to pay GST?
key_points.answer: If you are a salaried IT professional earning ₹10 LPA, you do NOT need to pay GST. GST applies only to business income, not salary income. However, if you have freelance/consulting income on the side, different rules apply.
detailed_explanation: - Salary income is NOT subject to GST
- You pay only Income Tax (TDS deducted by employer)
- No GST registration required regardless of salary amount
- GST registration threshold: ₹20 lakhs annual turnover (₹10 lakhs for special category states)
- If annual turnover is below ₹20 lakhs: GST registration optional
- If annual turnover exceeds ₹20 lakhs: GST registration mandatory
**Important:** Annual turnover means total business revenue, not salary. For freelancers earning ₹10 LPA from consulting, they are below the threshold and registration is optional.

key_points.question: What GST rate applies to IT services?
key_points.answer: IT services attract 18% GST (9% CGST + 9% SGST for intrastate, or 18% IGST for interstate). However, you only charge GST if you are registered.

key_points.question: Registration threshold for IT professionals 2024
key_points.answer: ₹20 lakhs annual turnover for general category states, ₹10 lakhs for special category states (NE states, J&K, Himachal, Uttarakhand)

details.mandatory: Above threshold - must register within 30 days

key_points.question: Income Tax vs GST - what's the difference?
key_points.answer: Income Tax is on your income (salary, profits). GST is on supply of goods/services. A salaried person pays Income Tax but not GST. A freelancer pays both Income Tax (on profit) and GST (on services provided to clients).

income_tax.applies_to: All income - salary, business profit, capital gains
income_tax.for_10_lpa_salary: Approx ₹1.12 lakhs per year (after ₹50k standard deduction + ₹1.5L 80C)

gst.who_pays: Only businesses/freelancers above threshold OR voluntary registration

key_points.question: Should I register for GST voluntarily if earning below ₹20 lakhs?
key_points.answer: Consider voluntary registration if: (1) Your clients are GST-registered businesses who want input tax credit, (2) You want to appear more professional, (3) You plan to grow beyond threshold soon. Otherwise, registration is optional and adds compliance burden.
pros: Clients get Input Tax Credit (ITC) on your invoices
Can claim ITC on your business expenses
Easier to work with large corporates
cons: Need to charge 18% more from clients (unless absorbed)

key_points.question: How much GST would I pay on ₹10 LPA freelance income?
key_points.answer: If you're a freelancer earning ₹10 LPA and register for GST, you would collect 18% GST from clients (₹1.8 lakhs) and deposit it to government after claiming input tax credit on your expenses.

calculation_example.note: This ₹1.44 lakh is NOT your cost - you collect it from clients and pass to government

freelancer_10lpa_registered.gst: 18% collected from clients, deposited after ITC

common_mistakes: Thinking salary income attracts GST (it doesn't)
Confusing Income Tax with GST (they are different)
Assuming ₹10L income means ₹10L × 18% = ₹1.8L personal cost (it's not your cost, clients pay it)
Not understanding turnover threshold (₹20L not ₹10L for general states)
Forgetting that GST is on services provided, not income earned

legal_basis.act: Central Goods and Services Tax Act, 2017

summary: For IT professionals earning ₹10 LPA as salary: NO GST. For IT freelancers earning ₹10 LPA from consulting: Optional GST registration (mandatory only above ₹20L). If registered, 18% GST applies to your service invoices.
